Type.Name: IAdvancedHoleElementData
Type.Description: Allows access to Advanced Hole element data.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksIAdvancedHoleElementData is extended by the following:
<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICounterboreElementData">ICounterboreElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICountersinkElementData">ICountersinkElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IStraightElementData">IStraightElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IStraightTapElementData">IStraightTapElementData</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITaperedTapElementData">ITaperedTapElementData</see> After accessing the IAdvancedHoleElementData object, cast it to a hole type-specific object using one of the interfaces above and set the hole type-specific properties. To create an Advanced Hole feature, see the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole">IFeatureManager::AdvancedHole</see> Remarks.

Type.Description: Allows access to the Advanced Hole feature data.
Type.Remarks: RemarksTo create an Advanced Hole feature, see the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.AdvancedHole">IFeatureManager::AdvancedHole</see> Remarks.

Type.Name: IAdvancedSaveAsOptions
Type.Description: Allows access to all File > Save As options when saving a SOLIDWORKS Part, Assembly, or Drawing.

Type.Name: IAdvancedSelectionCriteria
Type.Description: Allows access to advanced component selection criteria for an assembly.

Example.Name: Select Assembly Components Using Advanced Selection Criteria
Select Assembly Components Using Advanced Selection Criteria

Type.Remarks: RemarksThis interface represents functionality in the Advanced Component Selection dialog that appears when you click Standard toolbar > Advanced Select. As of SOLIDWORKS 2021, you can <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAdvancedSelectionCriteria.SaveCriteria">save</see> criteria only in XML format. You can now <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAdvancedSelectionCriteria.LoadCriteria">load</see> either *.xml queries or *.sqy legacy queries. For more information, see the Assemblies > Basic Component Operations > Selecting Components > Advanced Component Selection topic in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Type.Name: IAngleMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to an angle mate or a limit angle mate feature.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Limit Angle Mate
Create and Edit Limit Angle Mate

Type.Remarks:
RemarksAn angle mate places selected items at a specified angle. A limit angle mate is an advanced mate that allows items to move within a range of angles. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate">IAngleMateFeatureData::IsAdvancedMate</see> to determine whether this is a limit angle mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create either an angle mate or a limit angle mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IAngleMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAngleMateFeatureData.ReferenceEntity">IAngleMateFeatureData::ReferenceEntity</see> or use IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2 to pre-select the reference entity using Mark = 67108864. Specify other properties of the AngleMateFeatureData object. To edit an angle mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to an AngleMateFeatureData object. Modify the AngleMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete this angle mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IAnnotation
Type.Description: Allows access to notes, weld symbols, datum tags, display dimensions, blocks, cosmetic threads, center marks, centerlines, and other annotation types.

Example.Name: Get Whether Note Contains Rich-embedded Text
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature

Type.Remarks: RemarksBecause IAnnotation is a high-level representation of all annotation types, it provides functions that are generic to all types of annotations. For example, every annotation has a name and position, so IAnnotation provides functions that access this data. Although IAnnotation has specific lower-level objects (such as <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.INote">INote</see>), it does not have any derived classes in the SOLIDWORKS API. This means that you cannot use an IAnnotation pointer to call functions in the lower-level objects. You also cannot use QueryInterface to obtain the underlying classes. Instead, SOLIDWORKS provides <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation.IGetSpecificAnnotation">IAnnotation::GetSpecificAnnotation</see>, which accesses underlying objects. Similarly if you are holding onto a lower-level class, then you can obtain the corresponding IAnnotation object using the GetAnnotation method of that class (see the

Type.Name: IAppearanceSetting
Type.Description: Allows access to visual property settings.

Example.Name: Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State

Type.Remarks:
RemarksAfter implementing this interface:
Set one or more properties in the IAppearanceSetting object. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetDisplayStateSetting">IModelDocExtension::GetDisplayStateSetting</see> to obtain an <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting">IDisplayStateSetting</see> object. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Names">IDisplayStateSetting::Names</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames">IDisplayStateSetting::ISetNames</see> to specify the display states. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Entities">IDisplayStateSetting::Entities</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities">IDisplayStateSetting::ISetEntities</see> to specify the components. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Option">IDisplayStateSetting::Option</see> to specify the display state scope of the setting. Get or set the visual properties for the specified display states, components, and scope using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues">IModelDocExtension::DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues</see>.

Type.Name: IAssemblyDoc
Type.Description: Allows access to functions that perform assembly operations; for example, adding new components, adding mate conditions, hiding, and exploding components.
Type.Remarks: RemarksThe SOLIDWORKS API includes functions that are common to all document types; for example, determining the file name associated with a document is a common operation. To expose common document-level functions, the SOLIDWORKS API uses the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> object. Events are implemented with delegates in the Microsoft .NET Framework. See the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks_namespace">Overview</see> topic for a list of delegates for this interface.

Type.Name: IAttribute
Type.Description: Allows access to an attribute's values.

Example.Name: Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature

Type.Remarks:
RemarksAn attribute is a piece of information that can be stored on a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IBody2">body</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2">component</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IEntity">entity</see> ( <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFace2">face</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IEdge">edge</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IVertex">vertex</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ILoop2">loop2</see>, or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature">feature</see>), and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">model</see> if null. After you place an attribute on an object, you can get the IAttribute object and get or set its parameter values. For example, you can place an attribute containing NC machining information on a face. You can then use that attribute in automation on the shop floor to know what feed or speed to use during the machining process. You can also add attributes to a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">document object</see>. From the attribute instance you can get the:
Attribute definition
Associated entity
Parameter values
Instance name

Type.Name: IAttributeDef
Type.Description: Allows access to an attribute definition.

Example.Name: Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature
Add Attribute to Feature and Include in Library Feature

Type.Remarks:
RemarksAn attribute definition is an application-specific data packet that is automatically saved with the SOLIDWORKS file and reloaded when the file is opened. An application can create <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttribute">attribute</see> data that is attached to an entity in a SOLIDWORKS document. The attribute definition describes a template for the data packet. The definition contains the names of the parameters in the attribute, their types and default values. It also allows you to create instances of the definition on entities in your model. The general sequence of steps in IAttribute creation is to:
Create an attribute definition (<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.DefineAttribute">ISldWorks::DefineAttribute</see>) Add parameters to the attribute definition (<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.AddParameter">IAttributeDef::AddParameter</see>) Register the attribute definition (<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.Register">IAttributeDef::Register</see>) Create instances of the attribute definition on objects throughout the model (<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAttributeDef.CreateInstance5">IAttributeDef::CreateInstance5</see>) Perform Steps 1 through 3 only once for each working session. In other words, perform Steps 1 through 3 when your DLL or EXE is initially loaded or run. Until the DLL is unloaded or the EXE is closed, you can create an unlimited number of instances of the attribute definition.

Type.Name: ICamFollowerMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a cam-follower mate feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA cam-follower mate:
Allows you to mate a cylinder, plane, or point on a cam-follower part to the tangent faces of a cam part. Appears in the FeatureManager design tree as either CamMateCoincident or CamMateTangent. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a cam-follower mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICamFollowerMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ICamFollowerMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> for each EntityType or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1 for the cam face and Mark = 8 for the cam-follower face or vertex. Specify other properties of the CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. To edit a cam-follower mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. Modify the CamFollowerMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete this cam-follower mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: ICenterMark
Type.Description: Allows access to a center mark or center mark set in a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView">drawing view</see>.

Example.Name: Get and Set Center Mark Set
Get and Set Center Mark Set
Get and Set Center Mark Set

Type.Remarks:
RemarksCenter marks are now annotations. Previously, center marks were features. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.GetAnnotation">ICenterMark::GetAnnotation</see> to access the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation">IAnnotation</see> APIs. If you use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObject6">ISelectionMgr::GetSelectedObject6</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISelectionMgr.GetSelectedObjectType3">ISelectionMgr::GetSelectedObjectType3</see> to retrieve center marks, then these values are returned:
swSelCENTERMARKSSYMS = 100 for the center marks that are annotations
swSelCENTERMARKS = 28 for the center marks that are features Both methods retrieve the ICenterMark object.
To...
Use...
Traverse center marks that are annotations
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetFirstAnnotation3">IView::GetFirstAnnotation3</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAnnotation.GetNext3">IAnnotation::GetNext3</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetFirstCenterMark">IView::GetFirstCenterMark</see>, and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.GetNext">ICenterMark::GetNext</see>
Retrieve center marks that are features
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetCenterMarkCount2">IView::GetCenterMarkCount2</see> and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView.GetCenterMarks">IView::GetCenterMarks</see>
Center marks are displayed using the document's default display attribute settings. If you want the setting to be local to this symbol, then set the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.UseDocDisplaySettings">ICenterMark::UseDocDisplaySettings</see> property to false and modify the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.ShowLines">ICenterMark::ShowLines</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.Size">ICenterMark::Size</see>, and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICenterMark.CenterLineFont">ICenterMark::CenterLineFont</see> properties as needed. A center mark set is a linear or circular pattern.

Type.Name: IChainPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a chain component pattern feature.

Example.Name: Create and Modify Distance Chain Pattern Feature
Create and Modify Distance Chain Pattern Feature
Create and Modify Distance Chain Pattern Feature

Type.Remarks:
RemarksThis interface supports the following chain component patterns:
distance distance linkage connected linkage Read <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects.htm">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see>. Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to populate the chain component pattern.
Entity to select Corresponding Chain Pattern PropertyManager control Selection mark Number of selections

Type.Name: ICoincidentMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a coincident mate feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA coincident mate:
Positions the selected faces, edges, and planes so they share the same infinite plane. Positions two vertices so they touch. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a coincident mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICoincidentMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ICoincidentMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the CoincidentMateFeatureData object. To edit a coincident mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a CoincidentMateFeatureData object. You cannot change the entities to mate by pre-selection. You must use ICoincidentMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate to modify them. Modify other properties of the CoincidentMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete this coincident mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: ICollision
Type.Description: Allows access to collision data.
Type.Remarks: RemarksSee the ICollisionDetectionManager remarks.

Type.Name: ICollisionDetectionGroup
Type.Description: Allows access to collision detection groups.
Type.Remarks: RemarksSee the ICollisionDetectionManager remarks.

Type.Name: ICollisionDetectionManager
Type.Description: Allows access to the collision detection manager.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksThe purpose of this interface, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup">ICollisionDetectionGroup</see>, and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollision">ICollision</see> is to provide dynamic, high-efficiency collision detection among groups of components. Collision detection is performed exclusively between collision groups: neither within collision groups nor outside of them. Please use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IInterferenceDetectionMgr">IInterferenceDetectionMgr</see> if you need to perform static interference detection between components. Collision detection may be thought of as a series of collision detection frames. Each collision detection frame begins by setting a target assembly and two or more collision groups of components that are transformed to move to precise locations in model space. A collision detection frame may or may not end with a collision. NOTE: If a collision is detected, an ICollision object is created. Be aware that ICollision objects are volatile and should not be cached for later review. ICollision objects are invalidated when a new collision detection frame begins or whenever you:
call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.IsCollisionPresent">ICollisionDetectionManager::IsCollisionPresent</see>. call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.GetCollisions">ICollisionDetectionManager::GetCollisions</see>. apply new transforms to collision group components. create new or modify existing collision groups. set a new target assembly. Because you cannot save ICollision objects for later review, you should record the collision detection frame setup and any resulting collision components and transforms before the next collision detection frame begins. The workflow to detect collisions:
Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.SetAssembly">ICollisionDetectionManager::SetAssembly</see> to set the target assembly for collision detection. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionManager.CreateGroup">ICollisionDetectionManager::CreateGroup</see> to create two collision groups. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup.SetComponents">ICollisionDetectionGroup::SetComponents</see> to populate each collision group. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICollisionDetectionGroup.ApplyTransforms">ICollisionDetectionGroup::ApplyTransforms</see> to transform components into working positions. Call ICollisionDetectionManager::IsCollisionPresent and/or ICollisionDetectionManager::GetCollisions to detect collisions. Inspect any resulting ICollision objects. (See the NOTE above.) Repeat steps 4-6 if you want to apply new transforms for the next collision detection frame. Repeat steps 2-6 if you want to change collision groups. Repeat steps 1-6 if you want to change the target assembly.

Type.Description: Allows add-in applications to create tabs and add them to the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ICommandManager">CommandManager</see>. The add-in application must create and clean up its own tabs.

Example.Name: Create CommandManager Tab and Tab Boxes

Type.Remarks: RemarksYour add-in must check to see if the tab already exists. If the tab already exists, then you should use that tab instead of creating a new tab. If your add-in does not check for an existing tab, then SOLIDWORKS will create a new tab each time it starts up. Users can add buttons to and remove buttons from your CommandManager tab. However, if your add-in removes the CommandManager tab upon exiting SOLIDWORKS, then any customizations made by users will be lost.

Type.Name: IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a complex corner treatment feature of a structure system.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksThis interface is:
derived from <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData</see>. valid only if <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentFeatureData.IgnoreCornerTreatment">ICornerTreatmentFeatureData::IgnoreCornerTreatment</see> is false. A complex corner is the position in a structure system where three or more members intersect. In the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface, the Complex Corner PropertyManager contains five lists that you can manage using the APIs in this interface and elsewhere:
<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICornerTreatmentGroupFolder.GetCornerTreatments">Corner groups</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetTrimToolMember">Trim tool</see> member <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetBodyTrimMembers">Body trim</see> members <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.GetPlanarTrimMembers">Planar trim</see> members <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IComplexCornerTreatmentFeatureData.UserDefinedTrimFaces">User defined trim</see> faces You can assign one member as a trim tool and use it to add or remove material from adjacent members. Other members are trimmed based on their designated trim orders and positions with respect to touching members. For more information, see:
SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Corner Management > Trimming Complex Corners SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Corner Management > Examples of Complex Corner Management SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Weldments and Structure System > Structure System > Complex Corner PropertyManager

Type.Name: IConcentricMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a concentric mate feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA concentric mate:
Places selections so that they share the same axis. Can be configured to prevent rotation. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a concentric mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConcentricMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IConcentricMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the ConcentricMateFeatureData object. To edit a concentric mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a ConcentricMateFeatureData object. Modify the ConcentricMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete this concentric mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IConvertSolidFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a convert solid feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksTo create a ConvertSolid feature:
Ensure that the Sheet Metal tab is visible on the CommandManager toolbar. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to select the fixed face (with Mark=0) and bend edges (with Mark=1). Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition</see>(swFmSolidToSheetMetal) to create this feature data object. Instantiate and specify the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance">ICustomBendAllowance</see> object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.Initialize">IConvertSolidFeatureData::Initialize</see>. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see> to create the ConvertSolid feature. To modify a ConvertSolid feature:
Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to obtain this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.AccessSelections">IConvertSolidFeatureData::AccessSelections</see>. Modify properties as needed. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see> to finalize any changes or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConvertSolidFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IConvertSolidFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> if no changes were made. For more information about converting solids or surface bodies to sheet metal parts, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface online help > Sheet Metal > Comparing Sheet Metal Design Methods > Convert to Sheet Metal Tool topics.

Type.Name: ICoordinateSystemElement
Type.Description: Allows access to a coordinate system element.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksThe normal channel of feature editing (IFeature::CreateDefinition, IFeature::ModifyDefinition) will not work for features created with coordinate system elements. In order to edit a feature created with a coordinate system element, you must:
Select the feature created with a coordinate system element. Call the IModelDocExtension::RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_EditFeature to open a PropertyManager dialog for the selected object. Call ISelectionMgr::GetSelectedObjectType3 to obtain the selection. Test whether the selection is a coordinate system element. If the selection is a coordinate system element, obtain the CoordinateSystemElement object.
'VBA '---------------------------------------------------------------------' Preconditions:' 1. Open a part that contains an Axis1 created using a coordinate system element.' 2. Open the Immediate window.'' Postconditions:' 1. Examine the Immediate window to see the coordinate system element type as defined by swCoordSysElementType_e.' 2. Examine the user interface. The specified coordinate system element should be selected.''---------------------------------------------------------------------Option ExplicitDim swApp As SldWorks.SldWorksDim swModel As SldWorks.ModelDoc2Dim swSelMgr As SldWorks.SelectionMgrDim iSelType As LongDim isCoordSysElmSelected As BooleanDim swCordSysElement As SldWorks.CoordinateSystemElementDim boolstatus As Boolean Sub main() Set swApp = Application.SldWorks Set swModel = swApp.ActiveDoc boolstatus = swModel.Extension.SelectByID2("Axis1", "AXIS", 0, 0, 0, False, 0, Nothing, 0) swModel.Extension.RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_EditFeature, "" Set swSelMgr = swModel.SelectionManager iSelType = swSelMgr.GetSelectedObjectType3(1, -1) If iSelType = swSelCOORDSYS Then isCoordSysElmSelected = swSelMgr.IsCoordSysElementSelected(1, -1) If isCoordSysElmSelected Then Set swCordSysElement = swSelMgr.GetSelectedCoordSysElement(1, -1) Debug.Print "Element type: " & swCordSysElement.GetElementType End If End If swModel.Extension.RunCommand swCommands_e.swCommands_Dve_Rmb_Cancel, "" Set swCordSysElement = Nothing End Sub

Type.Name: ICustomBendAllowance
Type.Description: Allows access to the custom bend allowance of a feature.

Example.Name: Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data
Get All Sheet Metal Feature Data

Type.Remarks:
RemarksIn your application, the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance.Type">ICustomBendAllowance::Type</see> must always be set last, after the other properties of this interface have been set. The property last set automically overrides any previously set ICustomBendAllowance::Type.
For example:
cba.Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDeduction '***set first, so will not hold*** '***RESET THE VALUES*** cba.KFactor = 0.08 cba.BendDeduction = 0.1 cba.BendAllowance = 0.11 cba.BendTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba.BendCalculationTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba.Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect '***set last, so holds****
The above code sets the ICustomBendAllowance::Type as swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect.
Another example:
cba.Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDeduction '***set first, so will not hold*** '***RESET THE VALUES*** cba.KFactor = 0.08 cba.BendDeduction = 0.1 cba.BendAllowance = 0.11 cba.BendTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" cba.BendCalculationTableFile = "E:\AAA Projects\sw2025\QA\SP02\Convert To Sheetmetal FUN156195\1-Staal.xls" ‘cba.Type = swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceDirect '***set last would hold**** BUT COMMENTED OUT
The above code sets the ICustomBendAllowance::Type as swBendAllowanceTypes_e.swBendAllowanceBendCalculationTable, because the last property set was BendCalculationTableFile. The last ICustomBendAllowance property that is set automatically re-sets the type of bend allowance. You can always explicitly specify the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ICustomBendAllowance.Type">ICustomBendAllowance::Type</see>, but you must set it after all other properties of this interface have been set.

Type.Name: IDSPBRMaterial
Type.Description: Allows access to Dassault Systemes Physically Based Rendering (DSPBR) material object.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksThe Enterprise PBR Shading Model (DSPBR) is a high-quality, easy-to-use material optimized for performance in real-time and interactive scenarios, suitable for rasterization and ray tracing. Inspired by the Disney Principled BRDF and the Unreal Shading Model, it combines a metallic and a dielectric bidirectional scattering distribution function (BSDF), including transparency for thin-walled and volumetric objects. In addition, it provides effects like emission, clear coat, metallic flakes and sheen to cover a wide range of appearances. For the DSPBR design rationale and detailed mathematical description in terms of BSDF and related concepts, open https://dassaultsystemes-technology.github.io/EnterprisePBRShadingModel/spec-2025x.md.html in an internet browser. The properties in IDSPBRMaterial map to the appearance settings in the user interface, if the DSPBR appearance is activated in the user interface. To activate the DSPBR appearance in the SOLIDWORKS Design user interface:
Select System Options > Display > Appearance Visual Style > DSPBR (Dassault Systemes Physically Based Rendering). Open a model. Select MMGS in the unit system dropdown below the graphics area. Click Edit Appearance in the graphics toolbar. Click the DSPBR tab in the FeatureManager. Select Enerprise PBR Shading Model from the DSPBR Appearance Type dropdown.

Type.Remarks:
RemarksRead <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects.htm">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see>. Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the derived pattern feature. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to select the seed components and pattern feature in any order using Marks:
seed component = 1
pattern feature = 2 You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the derived pattern feature.
NOTE: A derived pattern feature is also called a pattern driven pattern feature. For more information, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Assemblies > Basic Component Operations > Component Patterns > Pattern Driven Component Pattern PropertyManager topic.

RemarksRead <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects.htm">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see>. The variable pattern feature uses a table to store the dimensions and values of pattern instances. You can <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDimPatternFeatureData.ImportFromExcel">import tables</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDimPatternFeatureData.ExportToExcel">export tables</see> using this interface. Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the derived pattern feature. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to select the reference geometry to drive the seed fature and the feature to pattern in any order using Marks:
reference geometry to drive seed feature = 1048576
feature to pattern = 4 You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the derived pattern feature.

This interface accesses the tolerances, datums, and datum modifiers that are set in this dialog. Type.Name: IDisplayDimension
Type.Description: Represents instances of dimensions displayed in <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc">parts</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc">assemblies</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc">drawings</see> and <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISensor">sensors</see>.

Example.Name: Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Get DimXpert Display Dimensions and Feature
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension
Set Properties of Angular Running Dimension

Type.Remarks: RemarksYou can display a SOLIDWORKS dimension more than once. For example, you can bring the base-extrude dimension into three different views on a drawing. These three dimensions are referred to as display dimensions and are represented by the DisplayDimension object in the SOLIDWORKS API. The original base-extrude dimension is represented by the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDimension">Dimension</see> object in the SOLIDWORKS API. SOLIDWORKS stores many of the properties associated with a dimension with the underlying Dimension object. For example, you must get the Dimension object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayDimension.GetDimension">IDisplayDimension::GetDimension</see> to access or modify the underlying dimension value.

Type.Name: IDisplayStateSetting
Type.Description: Allows access to display state settings.

Example.Name: Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State
Change Color of Component in Specific Display State

Type.Remarks:
RemarksAfter accessing this interface:
Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Names">IDisplayStateSetting::Names</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetNames">IDisplayStateSetting::ISetNames</see> to specify the display states. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Entities">IDisplayStateSetting::Entities</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.ISetEntities">IDisplayStateSetting::ISetEntities</see> to specify the entities. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDisplayStateSetting.Option">IDisplayStateSetting::Option</see> to specify the display state scope of the setting. Get or set one or more of the following properties for the specified display states, entities, and scope:
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayMode">IModelDocExtension::DisplayMode</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.Transparency">IModelDocExtension::Transparency</see> <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.Visibility">IModelDocExtension::Visibility</see> Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetAppearanceSetting">IModelDocExtension::GetAppearanceSetting</see> to obtain an <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAppearanceSetting">IAppearanceSetting</see> object. Set the properties in the IAppearanceSetting object. Get or set the material properties for the specified display states, entities, and scope using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues">IModelDocExtension::DisplayStateSpecMaterialPropertyValues</see>.

Type.Name: IDistanceMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a distance mate or a limit distance mate feature.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Limit Distance Mate
Create and Edit Limit Distance Mate

Type.Remarks:
Remarks A distance mate places selected items at a specified distance. A limit distance mate is an advanced mate that allows components to move within a range of distances. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDistanceMateFeatureData.IsAdvancedMate">IDistanceMateFeatureData::IsAdvancedMate</see> to determine whether this is a limit distance mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create either a distance mate or a limit distance mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDistanceMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IDistanceMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the DistanceMateFeatureData object. To edit a distance mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a DistanceMateFeatureData object. Modify the DistanceMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete a distance mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IDocumentSpecification
Type.Description: Allows you to specify how to open a model document. Use this interface's properties before calling <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.OpenDoc7">ISldWorks::OpenDoc7</see> to specify how you want to open a model document.

<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.FileName">IDocumentSpecification::FileName</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.ConfigurationName">IDocumentSpecification::ConfigurationName</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.DocumentType">IDocumentSpecification::DocumentType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.DisplayState">IDocumentSpecification::DisplayState</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.InteractiveAdvancedOpen">IDocumentSpecification::InteractiveAdvancedOpen</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.InteractiveComponentSelection">IDocumentSpecification::InteractiveComponentSelection</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IDocumentSpecification.LoadExternalReferencesInMemory">IDocumentSpecification::LoadExternalReferencesInMemory</see>

Type.Name: IDrawingComponent

Type.Remarks: RemarksThis object ties the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IComponent2">IComponent2</see> object of the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc">IAssemblyDoc</see> object with the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IView">IView</see> object of the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IDrawingDoc">IDrawingDoc</see> object. This functionality allows an application to manipulate the drawing-related settings of a referenced component without having to preselect that component.

Type.Remarks: RemarksCreating, aligning, and accessing drawing views are a few of the functions you find on the IDrawingDoc object. The SOLIDWORKS API also includes functions that are common to all document types. For example, determining the file name associated with a document is a common operation. The SOLIDWORKS API uses the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDoc2">IModelDoc2</see> object to expose common document-level functions. Events are implemented with delegates in the Microsoft .NET Framework. See the <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks_namespace">Overview</see> topic for a list of delegates for this interface.

You can find the file containing the list of supported geometric tolerance symbols and their abbreviations in C:\ProgramData\SolidWorks\SolidWorks 20nn\lang\english\gtol.sym.NOTE: All numeric values returned from IEnvironment are relative to a unit text height of 1.0; i.e., if a geometric tolerance symbol has a text height of 0.15, then multiply the numeric values returned by 0.15.

Type.Remarks:
RemarksThis interface is valid only for assemblies. To access the explode steps of an explode view of multibody parts, see <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartExplodeStep">IPartExplodeStep</see>. If this is a subassembly explode step, then you can call only one method on this interface, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IExplodeStep.GetSubAssemblyExplodeSteps">IExplodeStep::GetSubAssemblyExplodeSteps</see>, to retrieve the nested explode steps of this subassembly explode step. The setter properties and methods of this interface:
Always clear selection lists. Do not work if the Explode PropertyManager is open. Do not work if any component is being edited in the context of the assembly. To edit an explode step that is not a subassembly explode step:
Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IConfigurationManager.ActiveConfiguration">IConfigurationManager::ActiveConfiguration</see> to get the active configuration of the assembly. Access the explode step. See the

Type.Name: IExportPdfData
Type.Description:
Allows access to the PDF export data interface, which allows you to save:
one or more drawing sheets to PDF. parts and assemblies to 3D PDF.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksTo export one or more drawing sheets to PDF:
Get the IExportPdfData object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks::GetExportFileData</see>.
Set the sheets to export to PDF using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.SetSheets">IExportPdfData::SetSheets</see>.
Set whether to view the PDF after saving using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving">IExportPdfData::ViewPdfAfterSaving</see>.
Save the sheets using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SaveAs">IModelDocExtension::SaveAs</see>.
To export a part or assembly to 3D PDF:
Get the IExportPdfData object using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks::GetExportFileData</see>.
Set <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ExportAs3D">IExportPdfData::ExportAs3D</see> to true.
Set whether to view the PDF after saving using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IExportPdfData.ViewPdfAfterSaving">IExportPdfData::ViewPdfAfterSaving</see>.
Save the part or assembly using <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SaveAs">IModelDocExtension::SaveAs</see>.

Type.Name: IFillPatternFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a fill pattern feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksRead <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Pattern_Features_and_their_Feature_Data_Objects.htm">Pattern Features and their Feature Data Objects</see>. Before calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the fill pattern feature.
Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to select... For the Fill Pattern's... Using Mark...
Sketch, face, planar curve on a face, or coplanar faces Fill boundary
16384
Direction reference (e.g., edge or axis) Pattern direction (if not selected, SOLIDWORKS chooses a direction reference appropriate for the specified layout)
1
Vertex or sketch point Location of the pattern seed instance (if a point is not selected, the pattern seed instance is placed at the center of the fill boundary region)
3
Features Pattern objects 4
Faces Pattern objects 5
Bodies Pattern objects 6 After calling IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition, you can explicitly set other properties on the feature data object. You can also initialize:
<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.PatternLayoutType">IFillPatternFeatureData::PatternLayoutType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.LayoutSpacingType">IFillPatternFeatureData::LayoutSpacingType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.FeaturesToPatternType">IFillPatternFeatureData::FeaturesToPatternType</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.GeometryPattern">IFillPatternFeatureData::GeometryPattern</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFillPatternFeatureData.LoopSpacing">IFillPatternFeatureData::LoopSpacing</see> (for all PatternLayoutTypes except <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.swconst.swPatternLayoutType_e">swPatternLayoutType_e</see>.swPatternLayoutPerforation) Depending on the settings above, other properties might need to be initialized. You must call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see> after initializing this feature data object in order to successfully create the fill pattern feature. For all pattern layouts except swPatternLayoutType_e.swPatternLayoutPerforation, the fill pattern is created by positioning a pattern seed instance within the fill boundary and copying the pattern in concentric loops about the seed instance. See the Fill Pattern PropertyManager topic in the SOLIDWORKS Help for more information about fill pattern features.

Type.Name: IGearMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to gear mate features.
Type.Remarks:
Remarks A gear mate forces two components to rotate relative to one another about selected axes. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a gear mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IGearMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IGearMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1. Specify other properties of the GearMateFeatureData object. To edit a gear mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a GearMateFeatureData object. Modify the GearMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete a gear mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IGroundPlaneFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a ground plane feature.
Type.Remarks: RemarksUse this interface to insert a ground plane at each level of a plant assembly. Ground planes are used as reference geometry when inserting published assets at each level. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.ActivateGroundPlane">IAssemblyDoc::ActivateGroundPlane</see> to activate the ground plane on the level where you want to insert a published asset; the asset's ground face snaps to the assembly's activated ground plane. Components with magnetic mates snap only to components that are also on the active ground plane. Only one ground plane can be active at a given time in each assembly configuration. See Large Assemblies > Facility Layout in the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help.

Set Text in Datum Tags and GTols

Type.Name: IGtolFrame
Type.Description: Allows access to indicators and XML strings for symbols in a Gtol feature control frame.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA geometric tolerance symbol adds geometric tolerances to parts and drawings using feature control frames. This interface extends <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IGtol">IGtol</see> by supporting the new SOLIDWORKS 2022 Gtol architecture and providing the ability to specify Gtol frames using XML:
Left of Gtol you can add a single line of text and symbol (first frame only). Above Gtol you can add multi-line text and symbol (top frame only). Right of Gtol there can be indicator, datum, or text box. Multiple indicators are supported, but any text box must be at the end of the list of indicators. Text box can have only one line and symbol. Below Gtol there can be additional frames, text, between instruction, from-to instruction, separate requirement label (bottom frame only). For more information, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Detailing and Drawings > Annotations > Symbols > Geometric Tolerance Symbols topic.

Type.Name: IHingeMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a hinge mate feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA hinge mate:
Limits the movement between two components to one rotational degree of freedom. Can also limit the angular movement between two components. Acts like a concentric mate and a coincident mate. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a hinge mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IHingeMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">IHingeMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> for each EntityType or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities using Mark = 1 for the concentric entities, Mark = 32768 for the coincident entities, and Mark = 65536 for the angle entities. Specify other properties of the HingeMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a hinge mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a HingeMateFeatureData object. Modify the HingeMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete a hinge mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IImport3DInterconnectData
Type.Description: Allows access to 3D Interconnect feature data.

Example.Name: Use 3D Interconnect to Import Third-Party Native CAD Files

Type.Remarks:
RemarksThis interface requires 3D Interconnect. Enable 3D Interconnect by:
Setting Tools > Options > System Options > Import > Enable 3D Interconnect. - or -
Calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.SetUserPreferenceToggle">ISldWorks::SetUserPreferenceToggle</see>(<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.swconst.swUserPreferenceToggle_e">swUserPreferenceToggle_e</see>.swMultiCAD_Enable3DInterconnect, True). Access this interface after importing a third-party native CAD file into:
an existing SOLIDWORKS part using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IPartDoc.InsertImportedFeature">IPartDoc::InsertImportedFeature</see>. an existing SOLIDWORKS assembly using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.InsertImportedComponent">IAssemblyDoc::InsertImportedComponent</see>. a new SOLIDWORKS part using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks::LoadFile4</see>. a new SOLIDWORKS assembly using ISldWorks::LoadFile4. Use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Is3DInterconnectFeature">IFeature::Is3DInterconnectFeature</see> to determine whether a feature is a 3D Interconnect feature and whether this interface applies. ISldWorks::LoadFile4 imports into the appropriate native SOLIDWORKS part or assembly as follows:
For both imported parts and assemblies, you can:
Determine whether an update is required (<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Is3DInterconnectUpdateAvailable">IFeature::Is3DInterconnectUpdateAvailable</see>) and update the model (<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.Update3DInterconnectModel">IFeature::Update3DInterconnectModel</see>). Edit the imported data using this interface, its accessor (IFeature::GetImportedFeatureParameters), or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.SetImportedFeatureParameters">IFeature::SetImportedFeatureParameters</see>. Break the link to the original third-party native CAD file using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.BreakLink">IFeature::BreakLink</see>. After you break a link, all references to the original CAD file are lost, and you can no longer change the features to transfer from the original file. For imported parts only, the native SOLIDWORKS file created is a copy of the original non-native file. The copy retains an external reference to the original third-party native CAD file. If the original CAD file is modified in its orginal application, the SOLIDWORKS copy can be updated to import those changes. Changes to the SOLIDWORKS copy do not propagate back to the original CAD file. For imported assemblies only, after import you must save the new SOLIDWORKS assembly in order for SOLIDWORKS to import and create a copy to edit. Only after saving the new SOLIDWORKS assembly can you edit the imported top-level assembly or break its reference links. Editing lower-level imported components or individually breaking their reference links is not supported. 3D Interconnect supports the following third-party native CAD file formats and versions:
ACIS: .sat, .sab, .asat, .asab for r1 - 2018 1.0 Autodesk® Inventor: .ipt for V6-V2018, .iam for V11 - V2018 CATIA® V5: .CATPart, .CATProduct for V5R8 - V5-6R2017 IGES: .igs, .iges for up to 5.3 JT: .jt for JT 8.x, 9.x, and 10.x PTC®: .prt, .prt.*, .asm.* for Pro/ENGINEER® 16 - Creo 4.0 Solid Edge®: .par, .asm, .psm for V18 - ST10 STEP: .stp, .step for AP203, AP214, AP242 NX™ software: .prt for UG 11 - NX 11

Type.Name: IImportDxfDwgData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify values when importing or inserting DXF/DWG data.

Example.Name: Import DXF File into Part Sketch
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert and Position DXF/DWG File in Drawing
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions
Insert DXF/DWG File and Add Dimensions

Type.Remarks:
Remarks When importing DXF/DWG data, you can:
Let SOLIDWORKS determine the default values:
Paper size and sheet scale are computed to fit the input data.
Length unit is determined from the header of the input DXF/DWG file.
Sheet name is the same as the layout name in the input DXF/DWG file. - or -
Set your own values by using:
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetImportFileData">ISldWorks::GetImportFileData</see> to obtain the IImportDxfDwgData interface.
Use the following methods with a Sheet argument of "" (an empty string), to set up your defaults before importing or inserting the file:
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetPaperSize">IImportDxfDwgData::GetPaperSize</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetPosition">IImportDxfDwgData::GetPosition</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.GetSheetScale">IImportDxfDwgData::GetSheetScale</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.ImportMethod">IImportDxfDwgData::ImportMethod</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.LengthUnit">IImportDxfDwgData::LengthUnit</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetPaperSize">IImportDxfDwgData::SetPaperSize</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetPosition">IImportDxfDwgData::SetPosition</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SetSheetScale">IImportDxfDwgData::SetSheetScale</see>
<see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportDxfDwgData.SheetName">IImportDxfDwgData::SheetName</see> NOTES:
Getting the IImportDxfDwgData interface does not get default values from the input file. Any values not set by you are set to the values computed by SOLIDWORKS.
If the DWG/DXF file has multiple sheets, use these methods with a valid layout name in the Sheet argument to set up sheet specific settings, which override the default settings. If any of the individual items are not specified for a given layout name, the value used is from the defaults (layout name ""). If the default value is not specified, SOLIDWORKS computes and uses a meaningful value for that item.
When inserting DXF/DWG data as a feature into the current model document, first select a plane or planar surface and then call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.InsertDwgOrDxfFile2">IFeatureManager::InsertDwgOrDxfFile2</see>. Call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks::LoadFile4</see> to import the DXF/DWG file as a new SOLIDWORKS model document.

Type.Name: IImportIgesData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify levels and values when importing IGES data.

Example.Name: Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File
Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File
Specify IGES Levels and Values, Then Import IGES File

Type.Remarks:
Remarks
If user preference <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/swconst/FileOpenOptionsGeneral.htm">swIGESImportShowLevel</see> is...
Then the IGES translator...
True
Displays the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user where the user can specify levels and values.
false and you retrieved IImportIgesData
Does not display the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user and allows you to specify the levels and values.
false and you did not retrieve IImportIgesData
Does not display the IGES-In Surfaces, Curves, and Levels dialog to the user and uses the default values.
To specify levels and values when importing IGES data:
1. Set the user preference swIGESImportShowLevel to false. 2. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetImportFileData">ISldWorks::GetImportFileData</see> to get IImportIgesData. 3. Use the IImportIgesData functions to specify the levels and values. 4. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldworks::LoadFile4</see> to load the file.

Type.Name: IImportStepData
Type.Description: Allows you to specify values when importing STEP data.
Type.Remarks:
Remarks
Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.GetExportFileData">ISldWorks::GetImportFileData</see> to get an IImportStepData interface pointer. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IImportStepData.MapConfigurationData">IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData</see> to specify how to map configuration data. Use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadFile4">ISldWorks::LoadFile4</see> to load the file. When IImportStepData is initialized, the current default environment setting, <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/swconst/FileOpenOptionsGeneral.htm">swImportStepConfigData</see>, initializes IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData unless you explicitly set IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData. Then the IImportStepData::MapConfigurationData setting overrides swImportStepConfigData for this import only.

Type.Name: ILayerMgr
Type.Description: Allows you to manage a drawing document's layers.
Type.Remarks: RemarksEach drawing document has its own ILayerMgr object and its own <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.ILayer">ILayer</see> objects. The ILayerMgr interface provides functions that allow you to manipulate and work with individual layers. This includes adding layers, setting the current layer, obtaining specific layers, etc. Layers are only supported in SOLIDWORKS drawing documents.

Type.Remarks: RemarksSee <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/OVERVIEW/Library_Features_and_LibraryFeatureData_Objects.htm">Library Features and LibraryFeatureData Objects</see>.

Type.Name: ILibraryFormToolFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to library forming tool feature data.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksTo create a library forming tool feature:
Ensure that the Sheet Metal tab is visible on the CommandManager toolbar. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByRay">IModelDocExtension::SelectByRay</see> to select a flat face (with Mark = 0) on which to use a forming tool. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition</see>(swFmFormToolInstance) to create this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.OverrideDocumentSettings">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::OverrideDocumentSettings</see> to specify flat pattern visibility options. Specify the forming tool and its rotation angle for placement using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.FormToolConfiguration">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::FormToolConfiguration</see>, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.FormToolPath">FormToolPath</see>, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.LinkToFormTool">LinkToFormTool</see>, and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.RotationAngle">RotationAngle</see>. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see> to create the feature. To modify a library form tool feature:
Select a new location by clicking on a flat face in the graphics area where to re-position and/or replace the forming tool. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to obtain this feature data object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.AccessSelections">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::AccessSelections</see>. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.SetPlacementFace">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::SetPlacementFace</see> to re-position the forming tool. Call ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::OverrideDocumentSettings to change the flat pattern visibility options. Modify ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::FormToolConfiguration, FormToolPath (a change to FormToolPath changes the feature name), LinkToFormTool, and RotationAngle. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see> to finalize any changes or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILibraryFormToolFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">ILibraryFormToolFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> if no changes were made. Forming tools are dies that dent, bend, stretch, or otherwise form sheet metal. For more information about forming tools, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface online help > Sheet Metal > Using Forming Tools with Sheet Metal topics.

Type.Name: ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to linear/linear coupler mate feature data.

Example.Name: Create and Edit Linear-Linear Coupler Mate
Create and Edit Linear-Linear Coupler Mate

Type.Remarks:
Remarks A linear/linear coupler mate establishes a relationship between the translation of one component and the translation of another component. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this advanced mate interface. To create a linear/linear coupler mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity1">ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData::MateEntity1</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData.MateEntity2">ILinearCouplerMateFeatureData::MateEntity2</see>. Specify other properties of the LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object as required. To edit a linear/linear coupler mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object. Modify the LinearCouplerMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete a linear/linear coupler mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Before calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition</see>, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the linear pattern feature.

<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternBodyArray">ILinearPatternFeatureData::PatternBodyArray</see>, <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternFaceArray">PatternFaceArray</see>, or <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.PatternFeatureArray">PatternFeatureArray</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILinearPatternFeatureData.D1EndCondition">ILinearPatternFeatureData::D1EndCondition</see> to specify either spacing and instances or offsetting from an up-to reference: If explicitly setting spacing and instances, use:

Before calling <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition</see>, you must pre-select the entities needed to create the curve-driven component pattern feature.

Sketch to define the pattern

Type.Name: ILockMateFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to lock mate features.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksA lock mate:
Maintains the position and orientation between two components. Fully constrains the components. Is like a rigid subasssembly of components. <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateFeatureData">IMateFeatureData</see> is the parent of this mate interface. To create a lock mate:
Follow general instructions in the <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CreateMate">IAssemblyDoc::CreateMate</see> Remarks. Specify <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ILockMateFeatureData.EntitiesToMate">ILockMateFeatureData::EntitiesToMate</see> or use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.SelectByID2">IModelDocExtension::SelectByID2</see> to pre-select the entities to mate using Mark = 1. To edit a lock mate:
Access its feature and call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> to get the MateFeatureData object. Cast the MateFeatureData object to a LockMateFeatureData object. Modify the LockMateFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see>. To delete this lock mate, use <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.DeleteSelection2">IModelDocExtension::DeleteSelection2</see>.

Type.Name: IMBD3DPdfData
Type.Description: Gains access to the details for publishing a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF.

Example.Name: Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Publish Text and Custom Properties from Theme to MBD 3D PDF
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Export BOM's Second Column to BOM Table Area
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF
Fire Notification When Publishing Part to MBD 3D PDF

Type.Remarks:
RemarksSOLIDWORKS Model Based Definition (MBD) is an integrated drawingless manufacturing solution for SOLIDWORKS. This interface and its methods and properties require that the SOLDWORKS MBD add-in be loaded. (<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadAddIn">ISldWorks::LoadAddIn</see>) The MBD3DPdfData object corresponds to the SOLIDWORKS MBD Publish to 3D PDF PropertyManager page. Typical steps for generating a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using the SOLIDWORKS API are:
Get the MBD3DPdfData object using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.GetMBD3DPdfData">IModelDocExtension::GetMBD3DPdfData</see>. Set the path and file name of the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF theme using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.ThemeName">IMBD3DPdfData::ThemeName</see>. Get standard and custom views using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetStandardViews">IMBD3DPdfData::GetStandardViews</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetMoreViews">IMBD3DPdfData::GetMoreViews</see>. Set standard and custom views using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.SetStandardViews">IMBD3DPdfData::SetStandardViews</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.SetMoreViews">IMBD3DPdfData::SetMoreViews</see>. Get and set text and custom properties in the theme using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.GetTextAndCustomProperties">IMBD3DPdfData::GetTextCustomProperties</see> and <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ITextAndCustomProperty">ITextAndCustomProperty</see>. Set the path for the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMBD3DPdfData.FilePath">IMBD3DPdfData::FilePath</see>. Generate the SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D PDF using <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IModelDocExtension.PublishTo3DPDF">IModelDocExtension::PublishTo3DPDF</see>. See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about MBD.

Type.Name: IMBDSTEP242Data
Type.Description: Allows access to the details for publishing a SOLIDWORKS MBD 3D STEP242 file.
Type.Remarks: RemarksSOLIDWORKS Model Based Definition (MBD) is an integrated drawingless manufacturing solution for SOLIDWORKS. This interface and its methods and properties require that the SOLDWORKS MBD add-in be loaded. (<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.ISldWorks.LoadAddIn">ISldWorks::LoadAddIn</see>) The MBDSTEP242Data object corresponds to the SOLIDWORKS MBD Publish to STEP242 PropertyManager page. See the SOLIDWORKS Help for details about MBD.

Type.Name: IMacroFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to the data that defines a macro feature.

Example.Name: Cut Body in Half Using Macro Feature

Type.Remarks:
Remarks
Macro features can...
For the rebuild function only, the macro associated with a macro feature cannot:
be inserted into a part, assembly, or drawing document
create multiple bodies
edit multiple existing bodies
insert a feature from a macro feature in the same model
edit definitions of other features if these features are in the same model as the macro feature
rebuild, roll back, or roll forward the FeatureManager design tree NOTE: These limitations are intended to prevent nested-feature regeneration in the model that contains the macro feature.
When the feature is creating multiple bodies, then the return value from the rebuild function should contain the array of bodies that are the result of the operation. <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.EditBodies">IMacroFeatureData::EditBodies</see> is not expected to contain a body when the rebuild function returns to SOLIDWORKS. When the feature is modifying a body and the result is multiple bodies, then IMacroFeatureData::EditBodies should contain all of the resulting bodies. Whether creating multiple bodies or modifying a body that results in multiple bodies, call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.EnableMultiBodyConsume">IMacroFeatureData::EnableMultiBodyConsume</see> from the <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/Macro_Features/Rebuild_Function.htm">rebuild</see> function to specify whether multiple bodies replace or append the original edit body in the FeatureManager design tree Solid Bodies folder. If your application allows the user to decide which bodies to keep, your application must determine what it means to select the bodies and subsequently store the selected bodies with the feature. To edit a macro feature in a drawing, do not use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.AccessSelections">IMacroFeatureData::AccessSelections</see>, <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.IAccessSelections">IMacroFeatureData::IAccessSelections</see>, or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IMacroFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IMacroFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> because the concept of a rollback bar does not exist. You can still use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IModifyDefinition2">IFeature::IModifyDefinition2</see> to update an IMacroFeatureData object. If the user decides to cancel the changes made to the IMacroFeatureData object, then discard the IMacroFeatureData object. This action is equivalent to using IMacroFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess. See <see href="https://help.solidworks.com/2026/english/api/sldworksapiprogguide/Macro_Features/Overview_of_Macro_Features.htm">Overview of Macro Features</see> for more information.

Type.Description: Allows access to various assembly mate parameters.
Type.Remarks: RemarksTo get the IMate2 object, you must first get it as a <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature">IFeature</see> object and then use <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetSpecificFeature2">IFeature::GetSpecificFeature2</see> or QueryInterface to return the IMate2 interface. The IMate2 object is actually a subfeature beneath a MateGroup feature. To access the IMate2 subfeature by traversing the FeatureManager design tree, you can call <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetFirstSubFeature">IFeature::GetFirstSubFeature</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IGetFirstSubFeature">IFeature::IGetFirstSubFeature</see> and then <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetNextSubFeature">IFeature::GetNextSubFeature</see> or <see cref="SOLIDWORKS.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.IGetNextSubFeature">IFeature::IGetNextSubFeature</see> when the current feature type is MateGroup.

Type.Name: IMateControllerFeatureData
Type.Description: Allows access to a mate controller feature.
Type.Remarks:
RemarksTo create a mate controller feature:
Use IAssemblyDoc::IsSupportedMatesAvailable to determine whether supportive mates exist for the assembly. If true:
Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IAssemblyDoc.CollectAllSupportiveMates">IAssemblyDoc::CollectAllSupportiveMates</see>. Pre-select the supportive mates to use to create the mate controller. Or call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.Initialize">IMateControllerFeatureData::Initialize</see>, passing in the supportive mates. Mates passed into the Initialize method are given precedence over pre-selected mates. The array passed in must contain IDispatch objects. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateDefinition">IFeatureManager::CreateDefinition</see> to create an IMateControllerFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.AddNewPosition">IMateControllerFeatureData::AddNewPosition</see> to add a new mate position to the mate controller. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.SetValues">IMateControllerFeatureData::SetValues</see> to set the values for all mates in a given mate position. If values are not specified or invalid values are specified, then the mate controller feature is created with default mate values (i.e., values used when the mate was created). Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.CreateFeature">IFeatureManager::CreateFeature</see>, passing in the IMateControllerFeatureData object. Call <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeatureManager.GetCreateFeatureErrors">IFeatureManager::GetCreateFeatureErrors</see>. To edit a mate controller feature, call:
<see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.GetDefinition">IFeature::GetDefinition</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.AccessSelections">IMateControllerFeatureData::AccessSelections</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IFeature.ModifyDefinition">IFeature::ModifyDefinition</see> <see cref="SolidWorks.Interop.sldworks.IMateControllerFeatureData.ReleaseSelectionAccess">IMateControllerFeatureData::ReleaseSelectionAccess</see> For more information about the Mate Controller feature, see the SOLIDWORKS Design user-interface help > Assemblies > Mates > Mate Controller topic.
